medium_description_en: Predicts cancer mortality from serum biomarkers.

seo.meta_description_en: The Prognostic Index for Cancer Outcomes predicts cancer mortality from serum biomarkers.

how_to_use.pearls_pitfalls_en:
• The Prognostic Index (PI) has been evaluated across numerous different cancer cohorts and suggests incrementally worsening prognosis with increasing score.
  • Depending upon patient selection, stage, cancer, and other factors the resulting survival numbers vary widely.
how_to_use.why_use_en: Multiple studies suggest significantly worse outcome in patients with multiple types of cancer.

next_steps.advice_en: The Prognostic Index (PI) helps stratify prognosis groups and may be a worthy addition to multifactorial evaluations.
next_steps.management_en: We are unaware of validated management algorithms using the PI.
next_steps.critical_actions_en: The PI requires serum laboratory values and may be relevant when drawn prior to or after cancer diagnosis.

about.formula_en: Selection of appropriate levels of serum biomarkers.

Validation.text: Proctor MJ, et al. A comparison of inflammation-based prognostic scores in patients with cancer. A Glasgow Inflammation Outcome Study. Eur J Cancer. 2011 Nov;47(17):2633-41. doi: 10.1016/j.ejca.2011.03.028. Epub 2011 Jul 1.

Original/Primary Reference.text: Kasymjanova G, MacDonald N, Agulnik JS, et al. The predictive value of pre-treatment inflammatory markers in advanced non-small-cell lung cancer. Current Oncology. 2010;17(4):52-58.

creator_info.about_en: Goulnar Kasymjanova, MD, is an oncology researcher in the pulmonary diseases division at Sir Mortimer B. Davis Jewish General Hospital in Montreal, Canada. His research focuses on genetic profiling and prognostication of cancer, as well as patient responses to different chemotherapies.
